title: CS101: Data Structures & Algorithms Midterm
description: Midterm examination covering Big O notation, basic data structures (Arrays, Linked Lists, Stacks), and Python programming fundamentals.
subject: Computer Science

questions.text: What is the worst-case time complexity of accessing an element in a Hash Table (assuming many collisions and chaining)?
questions.explanation: While average case is O(1), in the worst case (all keys hashing to the same slot), it degrades to O(n) as you must traverse the linked list.

questions.text: Explain the LIFO principle in the context of a Stack data structure and provide one real-world computing example of its usage.
questions.correct_answer: LIFO stands for Last-In, First-Out. It means the last element added to the stack is the first one to be removed. A real-world example is the 'Undo' feature in text editors or function call management (call stack) in compilers.

example.description: Provides a valid computing example (Undo, Call Stack, Browser History)

questions.text: Write a Python function named `reverse_list` that takes a list of integers and returns a new list with the elements in reverse order. Do not use the built-in `reverse()` method or `[::-1]` slicing.
questions.explanation: Iterates backwards through the input list and appends to a new list.

questions.text: Convert the decimal number 42 to binary.
True or False: In a Singly Linked List, memory is allocated contiguously.
questions.explanation: Linked Lists nodes are allocated dynamically on the heap and can be scattered in memory; they are connected via pointers, unlike Arrays which are contiguous.

questions.text: Which of the following sorting algorithms is NOT stable by default?
questions.explanation: Quick Sort is inherently unstable because it swaps non-adjacent elements, potentially changing the relative order of equal keys. Merge, Insertion, and Bubble sorts are stable.

questions.text: Describe the difference between 'enqueue' and 'dequeue' operations in a Queue data structure.
questions.correct_answer: Enqueue adds an element to the rear (back) of the queue, while dequeue removes an element from the front of the queue. This follows the FIFO (First-In, First-Out) principle.

enqueue_definition.description: Correctly defines enqueue as adding to the rear

dequeue_definition.description: Correctly defines dequeue as removing from the front

questions.text: Given the following list of numbers inserted into an empty Binary Search Tree (BST) in order: [10, 5, 15, 3, 7]. What is the height of the resulting tree? (Assume the root is at height 0).
questions.explanation: Root is 10 (h0). Children are 5, 15 (h1). Children of 5 are 3, 7 (h2). The max depth is 2.

questions.text: Write a Python code snippet using the `.get()` method to safely retrieve the value for key 'age' from a dictionary named `student_data`. If the key does not exist, it should return -1.
questions.explanation: The get method takes two arguments: the key to look up, and a default value to return if the key is missing.
There are two nested loops, each running 'n' times. This results in n * n iterations, which is quadratic time complexity O(n^2).
